newsitem.title: USA: General Mills to raise cereal prices.
newsitem.headline: General Mills to raise cereal prices.

text.p: General Mills Corp., the nation's second largest cereal maker, said Wednesday it plans to increase prices an average of 2.6 percent, after cutting prices four times since 1993.
The maker of Cheerios, Lucky Charms and many other brands said the price increases, effective immediately, were intended to adjust for inflation.

A General Mills spokesman said he thought the increase was the first by a major cereal company since competitor Post Cereal, a division of Philip Morris Cos. Inc.'s Kraft Foods Inc. unit, shook up the $9 billion ready-to-eat cereal industry by cutting prices 20 percent.
General Mills, Quaker Oats Co. and leader Kellogg Co. followed that move to some extent. Analysts have said the price cuts failed to bring more consumers into the cereal aisles.
In a statement Wednesday, General Mills said that over the past four years, the prices of key components of the cereal company's cost structure have increased an average of 12 percent.
General Mills said the new prices remain lower than they were four years ago.
General Mills stock closed up 12.5 cents at $65.75 in consolidated trading Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange.
